TITLE: China’s Economy Stumbles in the Fog of Covid War
SUMMARY: Even if the country avoids new lockdowns of big cities, question marks over the pandemic and policy direction are dogging efforts to revive growth.

TITLE: In a Time of Conflict, Ukraine Entrepreneurs Make War Their Business
SUMMARY: From costume makers to consultants, fashion brands to uniform manufacturers, Ukrainian ventures have switched to producing goods to help wage war.

TITLE: What’s Next in the Elon Musk-Twitter Saga? A Court Battle
SUMMARY: Most legal experts say Twitter has the upper hand. But Musk revels in brinkmanship.

TITLE: The Fight Over Truth Also Has a Red State, Blue State Divide
SUMMARY: Several states run by Democrats are pushing for stiffer rules on the spread of false information, while Republican-run states are pushing for fewer rules.

TITLE: Could Twitter Force Musk to Close the Deal? Here’s What We Know
SUMMARY: Twitter is in a good position to sue under a legal doctrine called specific performance, which allows courts to force a transaction to be completed, even if one of the parties wants out.

TITLE: Germany on Edge as Nord Stream 1 Pipeline Goes Offline for Repair
SUMMARY: Supplies of natural gas via the Nord Stream 1 dropped to zero, as the pipeline began a 10-day maintenance period amid uncertainty over how long the shutdown would really last.

TITLE: Twitter’s Stock Falls Further as Doubts Swirl Over Musk’s Takeover
SUMMARY: Shares of the social media company have lost a third of their value since April 25, when Mr. Musk’s offer to buy the company was accepted by the company’s board.

TITLE: Oil Companies Oppose Windfall Tax in Britain Despie Record Profits
SUMMARY: Oil and gas companies say that charging them a 25 percent tax on profits could deter future investment at a critical time for Britain.

TITLE: Suspect in Abe Shooting Held a ‘Grudge.’ Scrutiny Falls on a Church.
SUMMARY: The Unification Church, with links to conservative political parties worldwide, said Monday that the mother of the man charged in Shinzo Abe’s death was a member.

TITLE: Does Public Art Have an Afterlife?
SUMMARY: Public artworks have the power to uplift a city. Sometimes they end up in a museum, but other times in a dumpster.

TITLE: Security Forces in China Attack Protesters Seeking Frozen Funds
SUMMARY: After a rare mass demonstration, bank depositors demanding their money back were beaten, kicked to the ground and dragged away in the city of Zhengzhou.

TITLE: A Glimpse Inside a Florentine Silk-Weaving Workshop
SUMMARY: The Antico Setificio Fiorentino, which relies on looms from the 18th and 19th centuries, has been producing precious textiles since 1786.

TITLE: Airline Pilots Seek Big Raises, and Broader Changes
SUMMARY: Pilots feel frustrated and overworked, issues that they say the air travel rebound has magnified by disrupting operations.

SUMMARY: More than 300 bookstores have opened in the past couple of years — a revival that is meeting a demand for “real recommendations from real people.”

SUMMARY: Some of the largest companies in the U.S. have pledged to adopt climate-friendly agricultural techniques. But some farmers say they haven’t provided enough incentive.

SUMMARY: Job growth remained strong last month. Company earnings season kicks off. And Elon Musk backs away from his deal for Twitter.

TITLE: Biden Seeks Price Cap on Russian Oil Amid Fears of Gas Shock
SUMMARY: Negotiating and selling the plan is a crucial task facing Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen as she travels to Asia in hopes of averting $7 a gallon gasoline.

TITLE: The Last Days of Suburban Office Parks
SUMMARY: With remote work and new norms, a concept that arose in postwar America is dying off. Emily Badger, who reported on the trend for The Upshot, shares more.

TITLE: A Day After Abe’s assassination, Campaigns Make a Final Push
SUMMARY: Shinzo Abe, Japan’s longest serving prime minister, was shot while campaigning for a candidate for the Upper House of Parliament.

TITLE: Bill J. Allen, Alaska Businessman at the Center of Scandal, Dies at 85
SUMMARY: He was one of the state’s most powerful figures, but his extensive corruption schemes brought him down — and took several politicians with him.

SUMMARY: The sweet spot of Arthur Aidala’s law practice is a headline-grabbing defendant who is hated by many. Somehow, that doesn’t mean people hate him.

SUMMARY: Russian gas cutoffs are causing huge losses for the utility in the “middle double-digit million” euro area, Uniper’s chief executive said.

SUMMARY: In two decades of flying, things have never been as stressful as they are now, a cabin insider says. Here, her tips from 30,000 feet for avoiding airline chaos this summer.

SUMMARY: Stringent rules on gun ownership had all but eradicated gun violence in the country.

SUMMARY: A bear market can be great for your future wealth, if you use broad, low-cost funds to buy stocks and bonds steadily for decades, our columnist says.

SUMMARY: Central bankers are closely watching wage growth, which has been picking up rapidly before accounting for inflation.

SUMMARY: Plus: Elon Musk may be preparing for the next chapter in his Twitter takeover journey — court.

SUMMARY: The strong Labor Department report comes as consumers and businesses express increasing concern about a downturn.

SUMMARY: Many employees of start-ups are attracted to the prospect of a big payout and an early retirement, but the strategy can require more luck than skill.

TITLE: Washington Post names David Shipley as its opinion editor.
SUMMARY: The newspaper said his job would be to expand the section nationally and globally.

SUMMARY: A central bank governor and president spoke in favor of a 0.75 percentage point rate increase this month, even as recession worries abound.

SUMMARY: The announcement drew criticism in part for its timing, a day after the deadly mass shooting in Highland Park, Ill.

SUMMARY: The operator of Tinder, Hinge and other dating sites said it would no longer give money to groups representing Republican and Democratic attorneys general.

SUMMARY: The e-commerce giant planned to build an airport cargo center, hire 1,000 workers and invest hundreds of millions of dollars over 20 years.

SUMMARY: Missing a celebration may feel awkward. But leave the boss out of it.

SUMMARY: A lack of child care and elder care options has forced some women to limit their hours or sidelined them altogether, hurting their career prospects.

SUMMARY: The chances are minuscule. But minuscule is not zero.

SUMMARY: The oil giant is benefiting from high prices in energy markets.
